questions.text: A 28 y/o female presents with a history of chronic constipation, rectal pain, and bleeding. On examination, an ulcer is found on the anterior wall of the rectum, 7 cm from the anal verge. Proctography reveals rectal intussusception. Which is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

A 55 y/o male presents with rectal bleeding and pain during defecation. O/E, a firm mass is palpable in the anal canal. A biopsy confirms carcinoma of the anal canal. Imaging shows no distant metastasis, but inguinal nodes are enlarged. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

A 60 y/o patient is diagnosed with anal canal cancer. A tumour of size 3cm invades through the muscularis propria into the perirectal tissue, involving 4-6 regional lymph nodes without distant metastasis. Which of the following stages correctly describes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Classification

Description

T0

No evidence of a primary tumour

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (localized)

Aka Bowens disease

Anal intraepithelial neoplasia(AIN) type I - III

T1

Tumor ≤ 2cm,

Invades the submucosa

T2

Tumor >2 cm but <5 cm,

Invades the muscularis propria

T3

Tumor>5 cm,

Invades the subserosa

T4

Tumour of any size that invades adjacent organs or structures eg. Vagina, urethra, Bladder

N0

No regional lymph node involvement

N1

Involvement of 1-3 regional lymph nodes

N2

Involvement of 4-6 regional lymph nodes

N3

Involvement of 7 or more regional lymph nodes

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

Stage

Criteria

Stage 0

Tis, N0, M0 (carcinoma in situ)

Stage I

T1-T2, N0, M0 (localized)

Stage II

T1-T2, N1, M0 (locally advanced)

Stage III

T1-T4, N2-N3, M0 (late locally advanced)

Stage IV

T1-T4, N1-N3, M1 (metastatic)

questions.text: A 58 y/o woman presents with anal pain, bleeding during bowel movements, and the presence of a palpable mass. She has a history of multiple sexual partners and was recently diagnosed with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Which of the following risk factors is most strongly associated with the development of anal canal cancer in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: HPV infection leads to anal condylomata.

options.label: B
options.text: Immunosuppression due to a recent organ transplant.

questions.correct_answer: A. HPV infection leads to anal condylomata.
questions.explanation:
Factor

Description

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection

Strongly linked to anal canal cancer, particularly high-risk subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33)

Anal Intraepithelial Neoplasia (AIN)

A precancerous condition significantly increases the risk of progression to anal canal cancer, especially from AIN II or III.

Immunosuppression

Individuals with weakened immune systems (e.g., HIV-positive, transplant recipients) have a higher risk due to impaired HPV response and AIN development.

Sexual Practices

Anal intercourse increases HPV transmission risk.

History of Other Genital Neoplasia

A history of vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) raises the risk.

Extensive Anogenital Condylomata

The presence of extensive anal warts linked to HPV infection elevates the risk of anal canal cancer.

questions.text: .A 78-year-old woman with a history of chronic constipation and faecal incontinence presents with a complaint of a mass that protrudes circumferentially from her anus, which she can manually reduce. She also reports occasional bleeding and difficulty with bowel movements. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's rectal prolapse?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Abdominal Rectopexy

Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

questions.text: A 58 y/o man presents with bright red blood in his stool, tenesmus, and intermittent abdominal pain for one month. A digital rectal exam reveals a hard mass 5 cm from the anal verge. Rigid sigmoidoscopy confirms a neoplasm. What is the next step to evaluate the extent of his disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

options.label: C
options.text: Obtain a biopsy of the rectal mass.

questions.correct_answer: A. Perform a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiencing severe pain during bowel movements, bright red blood on toilet paper, and chronic anal fissures has not improved with conservative treatment and is being referred for surgery. Which surgical procedure is aimed at reducing anal sphincter tone to promote healing of the fissure while maintaining continence?
questions.explanation:
Lifestyle and Dietary Modifications

Aim: To soften stools and reduce pain

  • Increase fiber intake
  • Adequate fluid intake
  • Warm Sitz baths to relax the anal sphincter.
  • Topical anaesthetics.
  • Anorectal biofeedback: Helps patients learn to relax the anal sphincter and improve bowel control.

Pharmacological Treatment
  1. Topical medications:
  • Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) ointment (0.2%): Applied 2-3 times daily; a nitric oxide donor that promotes relaxation but may cause headaches.
  • Diltiazem (2%): Applied twice daily; a calcium channel blocker that induces sphincter relaxation with fewer side effects compared to GTN.
  1. Botulinum toxin injections: 10-100 units injected into the internal anal sphincter to reduce pressure and allow healing by blocking acetylcholine release.

Lateral Internal Sphincterotomy

Divides a small portion of the internal anal sphincter.

Approaches:

  • Closed Method: Small incision over the intersphincteric groove to divide the sphincter under the mucosa.
  • Open Technique: Incision through the anoderm for direct access to the internal sphincter.

Fissurectomy (Option A ruled out)
  • Excision of the fissure, including fibrotic edges and associated skin tags.
  • Often combined with an anal advancement flap.

Anal Advancement Flap

(Option C ruled out)
  • Used when there’s an increased risk of incontinence after sphincterotomy, especially in women post-childbirth.
  • Involves advancing a flap of healthy skin from the perianal area to cover the fissure, promoting healing and reducing tension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a recurrent anal abscess has developed an anal fistula. She is concerned about continence after surgery. Which surgical option is best to treat her condition while minimizing incontinence risk?

options.label: D
options.text: Ligation of the Intersphincteric Fistula Tract (LIFT)

questions.correct_answer: D. Ligation of the Intersphincteric Fistula Tract (LIFT)
questions.explanation:
Treatment

Description

Indications

Fistulotomy

(Option A ruled out)

Opening the fistula tract to heal by secondary intention.

Used for intersphincteric and trans-sphincteric fistula involving <30% of external sphincter; not for anterior fistula in women.

Fistulectomy

(Option B ruled out)

Removal of the fistula using diathermy cautery for better visualization of anatomy.

Effective for understanding the fistula's anatomy and extensions.

Setons

(Option C ruled out)

Materials are inserted into the fistula tract for drainage or gradual cutting.

Loose setons promote drainage; tight/cutting setons cut through muscle over time.

Advancement Flaps

Closing the internal opening with a flap of anorectal mucosa is used when the sphincter complex is not extensively indurated.

Effective for certain fistula configurations.

questions.text: A 1-week-old girl with a newly diagnosed rectovestibular fistula is undergoing evaluation. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for a newborn with a rectovestibular fistula?

options.label: B
options.text: Initial colostomy followed by definitive pull-through operation

options.label: C
options.text: Wangenstein's Invertogram to determine the level of the rectal pouch

options.label: D
options.text: Aspiration of meconium and dye injection for fistula assessment

questions.correct_answer: B. Initial colostomy followed by definitive pull-through operation
questions.explanation:
Cause

Results from the imperfect fusion of the post-allantoic gut with the proctodaeum.

Incidence

Occurs in 1 in 4500 newborns; associated with anomalies like VATER/VACTERL, including cardiac, trachea-esophageal fistula, renal, and spinal anomalies.

Types
  • Male: Rectobulbar fistula (the fistula originating distal to the puborectalis)
  • Female: Rectovestibular fistula.

Investigations
  • Wangenstein's invertogram is used to determine the level of the rectal pouch relative to the pubococcygeal (Stephen’s) line.
  • Murugassu's technique: Involves aspiration of meconium from the rectum and dye injection to assess fistula level.
  • USG abdomen, cardiac function evaluation, MRI spine.

Treatment
  • Low Fistula: Single-stage reconstruction like anoplasty, ano vestibuloplasty, anal dilation, or incision of the anal membrane with excellent outcomes.
  • High Fistula: Initial colostomy followed by a definitive “Pull-through operation” (posterior sagittal anorectoplasty) and later colostomy closure.

Complications
  • Infection
  • Fecal fistula
  • Stenosis
  • Colitis
  • Malnutrition
  • Fecal incontinence

questions.text: A 62 y/o woman diagnosed with rectal carcinoma is being evaluated for treatment options. Which of the following statements regarding the treatment strategies for rectal carcinoma is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Total mesorectal excision (TME) is a method of palliative care in patients with advanced rectal cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is used after surgical resection to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

options.label: C
options.text: Local excision is indicated for early-stage rectal cancers with good prognostic factors.

options.label: D
options.text: Abdominoperineal excision (APR) is the preferred surgical approach for all cases of rectal carcinoma.

questions.correct_answer: C. Local excision is indicated for early-stage rectal cancers with good prognostic factors.
questions.explanation:
Technique

Indications

Local Excision

(Option C)

Suitable for early-stage cancers (T1 and selected T2) with good prognostic factors; preserves rectum and anal sphincter, minimizing bowel function impact.

Anterior Resection

Preferred for most cancers in the middle and lower rectum; involves removing affected rectal parts and reconnecting the colon to the remaining rectum.

Abdominoperineal Excision (APR)

(Option D ruled out)

Reserved for low-lying, extensive tumours unsuitable for sphincter-saving; involves removing rectum, anus, and surrounding tissues, creating a permanent colostomy.

Hartmann's Procedure

Involves removing the rectum and creating a temporary colostomy, suitable for elderly or frail patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with bright red, painless rectal bleeding and a feeling of incomplete evacuation. Digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals a firm, irregular, palpable mass located 6 cm from the anal verge. Which statement about the clinical features of rectal carcinoma is most accurate?

options.label: B
options.text: Rectal carcinoma typically presents without any changes in bowel habits.

options.label: C
options.text: Rectal carcinoma is most common in patients under 55 years of age.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of a hard mass within 7-8 cm of the anal verge.

questions.correct_answer: D. The presence of a hard mass within 7-8 cm of the anal verge.

questions.text: A 24 y/o male presents with intermittent pain and discharge at the natal cleft after experiencing recurrent abscesses in the area. He reports that the symptoms worsen after prolonged sitting and has a history of coarse hair. Upon examination, a midline opening is noted in the natal cleft. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Complete surgical excision of the sinus

questions.correct_answer: C. Drainage through a midline incision
questions.explanation:
Treatment Type

Description

Conservative Treatment
  • For mild cases: cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
  • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser in less complex cases.

Acute Abscess Treatment
  • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess (Option C).
  • Thorough cleaning of the abscess cavity to remove granulation tissue and hair.

Surgical Treatment

Procedures include:

  • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
  • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
  • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
  • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
  • Flap Procedures: Used if initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents with severe pain during bowel movements and bright red blood on toilet paper for 2 weeks. She describes the pain as excruciating and sharp, akin to "passing glass.” Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It mainly presents with anal itching & discharge

options.label: B
options.text: The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.

options.label: C
options.text: This condition is characterized by a thickened anal papilla and a skin tag.

options.label: D
options.text: The majority of cases occur in the anterior midline in women due to childbirth.

questions.correct_answer: B. The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Acute Anal Fissures

Chronic Anal Fissures

Cause

Trauma to the anal canal lining. (Passage of hard stools, prolonged diarrhoea, childbirth).

Increased anal sphincter tone converts acute to chronic fissure,

  • Elevated muscle tension reduces blood flow to the anal canal.
  • Impaired healing leads to a cycle of repeated injury.

Pain

Excruciating, sharp pain during defecation (described as "passing glass").

May be less intense than acute but can still be painful.

Duration of Pain

The pain subsides after defecation but returns with the next bowel movement. (Option B)

Persistent pain may occur, with periods of discomfort.

Bleeding

Bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping.

May also experience blood but less prominently reported.

Physical Exam

Difficult without anaesthesia due to intense pain.

An exam may be possible, with signs of irritation from the skin tag.

Additional Symptoms

Notable pain prevents physical examination; anal spasms may be present.

Presents with anal itching, discharge, or intersphincteric fistula. (Option A ruled out)

Identifying Features

Fresh, superficial tears in the anal canal.

Thickened anal papilla and skin tag present; fissure between these structures. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 35 y/o woman presents with severe pain during bowel movements and bright red blood on toilet tissue. Upon examination, the physician suspects an anal fissure. Which of the following characteristics is most likely associated with a chronic anal fissure?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of bright red blood only after bowel movements.

options.label: B
options.text: Severe sharp pain during bowel movements that subside afterwards.

options.label: C
options.text: Thickened anal papilla and skin tag are present at the fissure site.

questions.correct_answer: C. Thickened anal papilla and skin tag are present at the fissure site.
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Acute Anal Fissures

Chronic Anal Fissures

Description

Fresh, superficial tears in the anal canal lining.

Develop when acute fissures fail to heal due to ongoing trauma and increased anal sphincter tone.

Symptoms
  • Severe, sharp pain during bowel movements (subsides afterwards)(Option B ruled out)
  • Bright red blood on toilet tissue after wiping(Option A ruled out).
  • Physical examination often requires general anaesthesia due to pain.
  • Presence of a thickened anal papilla and an external skin tag(Option C).
  • May cause anal itching due to skin tag irritation.
  • Discharge from the fissure or a co-existing intersphincteric fistula.
  • Often less painful than acute fissures due to associated inflammation.

questions.text: During a detailed anatomical study, a researcher examines the fascia layers associated with the rectum. Which of the following structures separates the rectum from the prostate in males?

A 32 y/o male presents with intermittent discharge of pus from an external opening near the anus, accompanied by discomfort and occasional blood in the discharge. He has a history of anorectal abscess treated six months ago and reports pain during bowel movements. Which of the following is the investigation of choice in this case?
questions.explanation:
MRI (Option D)

Maps the fistula tunnel and provides detailed images of the sphincter muscle and pelvic floor structures. (Investigation of choice)

Endoscopic Ultrasound (Option B ruled out)

It uses high-frequency sound waves to identify the fistula, sphincter muscles, and surrounding tissues.

Fistulography (Option A ruled out)

An X-ray procedure using injected contrast to visualize the anal fistula tunnel.

Examination Under Anesthesia

Allows for thorough evaluation of the fistula tunnel and identification of potential complications.

Fistula Probe

A specialized instrument is inserted through the fistula to identify the fistula tunnel.

Anoscopy (Option C ruled out)

A small endoscope is used to visualize the anal canal for assessment of fistulas during anoscopy

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents to the clinic with a persistent anal discharge and discomfort. He has a history of recurrent perianal abscesses over the past year. O/E an external opening is noted near the anal margin. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the anal fistula in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis. (Option D)
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease(Option A ruled out)
    • Tuberculosis (Option B ruled out)
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis (Option C ruled out)
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)
 

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with severe anal pain and a tender, indurated lump at the anal margin. He reports a two-day history of progressively localized pain but has no systemic symptoms such as fever or malaise. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Anatomy

Clinical Features

Perianal Abscess

Surrounds the anus, becoming continuous with buttock fat laterally.

Painful swelling at the anal verge, easily diagnosed via physical exam.

Ischiorectal Abscess

Located lateral and posterior to the anus, connected posteriorly by the deep postanal space.

Large, often non-visible swelling in the perianal area; detected by digital rectal exam.

Intersphincteric Abscess

Lies between the internal and external anal sphincters, extending from the perianal space to the rectal wall

Severe pain, exacerbated by coughing or sneezing. Diagnosed by DRE under anaesthesia.

Supralevator Abscess

Located above the levator ani on either side of the rectum, it may communicate with intersphincteric or ischiorectal abscesses.

An indurated bulging mass above the anorectal ring

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male reports deep, intense pain "inside" the anal area that worsens with coughing or sneezing. The examination shows minimal external swelling, but the significant discomfort prevents a complete digital rectal exam. Given this clinical picture, which type of anorectal abscess is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Features

Perianal abscess (60%)(Option A ruled out)
  • Most common type; involves the suppuration of anal glands or infected perianal conditions
  • Located near the external sphincter.

Ischiorectal Abscess (30%)

(Option B ruled out)
  • 2nd most common; occurs in the ischiorectal fossa due to poor vascularization;
  • Presents with tender swelling, fever;
  • Treated with surgical drainage.

Submucous Abscess (5%)
  • Occurs above the dentate line, presenting with aching anorectal pain
  • O/E tender swelling felt on the rectal exam;
  • Treated with antibiotics and drainage.

Supralevator Abscess

(Option D ruled out)
  • Uncommon
  • Mimics intra-abdominal lesions
  • Diagnosed by DRE
  • Treatment: The drainage method depends on the abscess origin;
    • Intersphincteric abscesses- drained rectally,
    • Ischiorectal abscesses- drainage through the ischiorectal fossa.
    • Intra-abdominal disease- the primary condition is treated first, with abscess drainage via the most direct route.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with difficulty urinating and lower abdominal discomfort. The doctor advises a digital rectal examination (DRE) to assess for potential prostate enlargement or other rectal abnormalities. Which of the following is not an external inspection finding?
questions.explanation:
External Inspection

Internal Inspection
  • Anal fissures (Option A)
  • Anal fistula
  • Genital warts
  • External haemorrhoids (Option D)
  • Pilonidal sinus (Option C)
  • Skin disease (seborrhoeic eczema, skin cancer, natal cleft dermatitis)
  • Skin tags
  • Skin discoloration with Crohn's disease
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Internal haemorrhoids
  • Rectal carcinoma
  • Rectal polyps
  • Tenderness with prostatitis or acute appendicitis
  • Malignant or inflammatory conditions of the peritoneum with anterior palpation

questions.text: A 72-year-old multiparous woman presents with a painless mass protruding from her anus along with occasional bleeding and fecal incontinence. O/E the mass is circumferential, red in colour, and reducible. Which of the following is the most likely type of rectal prolapse?
questions.explanation:
Infants and Children
  • Decreased sacral curvature
  • Decreased anal canal tone
  • Chronic constipation with straining
  • Cough
  • Malnutrition

Anatomical and Physiological Factors
  • Diastasis of the levator ani
  • Abnormally deep cul-de-sac
  • Redundant sigmoid colon
  • Patulous sphincter
  • Loss of rectal sacral support
  • Lax and atonic pelvic floor musculature

Adults
  • More common in females
  • Common in multiparous women due to repeated birth injuries
  • Damage to the perineal nerve supply
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., chronic cough, stricture urethra)

Partial

Complete
  • Mucosal
  • There is no descent of the muscular layer.
  • It is the most common type of rectal prolapse.
  • History of mass per anum, It is pink in colour and circumferential.
  • Complete-full thickness.
  • The descent contains all layers of the rectum (i.e. including the muscular layer).
  • Complete descent of rectum as mass per anum circumferentially which is red in colour. Mass is usually reducible and painless.
  • It may be associated with uterine prolapse (uterine procidentia) in females.
  • Fecal incontinence (75%) is very common.
  • Bleeding can occur because of the congestion.
  • Sepsis, discharge, fever, and anaemia are other features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent bleeding from haemorrhoids despite dietary changes and non-operative treatments. Examination reveals third-degree internal haemorrhoids. Which of the following is not an indication of hemorrhoidectomy?

options.label: C
options.text: 'Mixed' haemorrhoids with a well-defined external component

questions.explanation:
Closed Haemorrhoidectomy

The Parks or Ferguson hemorrhoidectomy involves resection of hemorrhoidal tissue and closure of the wounds with an absorbable suture.

Open Haemorrhoidectomy

In Milligan and Morgan hemorrhoidectomy, wounds are left open and allowed to heal by secondary intention

Whitehead’s Hemorrhoidectomy

Whitehead’s hemorrhoidectomy involves circumferential excision of the hemorrhoidal cushions just proximal to the dentate line

Stapled Hemorrhoidectomy (Longo)
  • Procedure for Prolapse and Hemorrhoids (PPH), also known as stapled hemorrhoidopexy, is an outpatient procedure for second and third-degree haemorrhoids.
  • It uses a stapling device to remove redundant hemorrhoidal tissue and mucosa, ligate feeding venules, and fix the tissue above the dentate line.

Early

Late

● Pain

● Acute retention of urine

● Reactionary haemorrhage

● Secondary hemorrhage

● Anal stricture

● Anal fissure

● Incontinence

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with bright red bleeding during defecation and a prolapsed haemorrhoid that cannot be reduced manually. What is the most suitable management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Rubber Band Ligation

Effective for persistent bleeding in first, second, and selected third-degree haemorrhoids by strangulating tissue to prevent further bleeding or prolapse. (Option B ruled out)

Infrared Photocoagulation:

Suitable for small first and second-degree haemorrhoids, coagulating the underlying plexus.

Sclerotherapy

Involves injecting sclerosing agents into first, second, and some third-degree haemorrhoids to cause fibrosis. (Option C ruled out)

Excision of Thrombosed External Hemorrhoids

Elliptical excision under local anaesthesia for acutely thrombosed external haemorrhoids causing intense pain.

Operative Hemorrhoidectomy

Elective resection of symptomatic haemorrhoids by decreasing blood flow and excising redundant tissue.Used in 3rd and 4th-degree haemorrhoids (Option D)

Doppler-Guided Hemorrhoidal Artery Ligation

Uses a Doppler probe to identify and ligate arteries feeding the hemorrhoidal plexus, promising for symptomatic hemorrhoids but long-term effectiveness is still being evaluated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man reports experiencing bright red bleeding during bowel movements and a mass that protrudes from his anus, which he can manually reduce but does not reduce spontaneously. On examination, no thrombosed haemorrhoids are observed. Which degree of internal haemorrhoids is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Internal Haemorrhoids

External Haemorrhoids

Above the dentate line, covered with mucous membrane.

Below the dentate line, covered with skin.

Painless bleeding (covered by insensate anorectal mucosa)

Painful bleeding(anoderm is richly innervated, thrombosis of an external haemorrhoid may cause significant pain)

Treatment- depends on the degree

Treatment- excision of external haemorrhoids

questions.text: A 55 y/o woman presents with complaints of rectal bleeding and discomfort during bowel movements. She mentions experiencing chronic constipation and frequent straining. Which pathophysiological mechanism is most likely contributing to her haemorrhoids?

A 58 y/o male presents with rectal cancer located just distal to the dentate line. During his evaluation for metastatic spread, which lymph nodes are most likely to be involved given the location of his cancer?
